{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3752266,"name":"Ryan Radtke","username":"Ryanforce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryanforce/{size}/228665_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-30T13:33:03.185Z","cooked":"

Iâ€™m building an ARGB sign for our practice field that changes color to indicate whether the field is safe (green) or not (red). I want to control it with an ESP32 or Arduino by connecting to the Driver Station, so it could show red when the robot is enabled, with different modes for teleop, auton, etc. My issue is I canâ€™t figure out how to connect to the Driver Station. I originally considered NetworkTables, but I havenâ€™t found any C implementations. Any suggestions would be appreciated.

Are you running any sort of FMS?

At least on MacOS there is a networktables implementation on C++ in /Users/[yourname]/wpilib/2025/maven/edu/wpi/first/ntcore

It has the binaries for a lot of operating systems and the headers. Just be careful as ntcore depends on wpiutil and wpi so you will also have to add those to your CMakeLists.

I would recommend having the ESP/Arduino connect to the DS computer via a USB serial port type connection and running an application (Python would be a good choice, but Java is an option too) on the computer to command it. Thereâ€™s a dedicated DS TCP port that gives some information but Iâ€™m not sure it includes match state; for NT from desktop there is pyntcore or the standard WPILib libraries that can be used, see Creating a Client-side Program â€” FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

So emulate the RSL with more functionality? I might suggest if your only displaying and getting the status of your robot and not all robots on the field that you add some 12vdc RGB LED lights.

Programming them could be as simple as using the built in WPILib RGB libraies or add a 3rd party controler from CTRE or Rev. This would be great feedback for everyone watching and is where everyone is focused on.

Our RGB LED strips on our robot tell us the following

  • Pre Match

    • Violet Robot Powered/ Not Connected to DS

    • Red/Blue assined alliance color

      • Fast Flash an error or an undesirable condition
      • Solid all good
  • in match
    • Violet Blink Searching for Reef
    • Green locked on Reef ready to score
    • Yellow blink Intake Coral
    • Green blink Coral Sensed
  • End game
    • Dancing Violet climbed and locked

NT require ethernet connection so your best bet would be using serial like what @Peter_Johnson mentioned.

Also speaking of NetworkTables,

image1280Ã—1707 168 KB

I am working on a implimentation of NT on ESP32 but it is far away from ready. Also currrently it only work thru wifi which is useless in competition.

github.com

Nope. Itâ€™s designed to tethered to one roborio and read its enable / disable status.

The python script does not talk to driver station. It connect to a network tables server which if itâ€™s a real robot itâ€™s running on roborio.

That is not FIRST FMS but rather cheesy arena.

I donâ€™t know exactly how that works but basically I would read the status of FMS ( Enable / disable ) using http or websocket (whatever cheesy use I donâ€™t know) and write a python script to translate that to serial command for ESP32 to set LED colour.

FIRST FMS is a black box, I would be surprised if there are any APIâ€™s for teams to tap into.

If youâ€™re using Cheesy Arena or Freezy Arena you can look into my GitHub - cpapplefamily/Freezy-Estops: ESP32 controlled collection of Estops and Astops for Freezy Arena

FIELD_TESTING_ENDPOINT = "/setup/field_testing/websocket" This is how my FreezyStop controller when deviceRole == "BARGE_LIGHTS"is collecting the stats of the barge lights. If you look at the field testing page of Cheesy you will see all the values that would be packed in that web socket.

deviceRole == "FMS_TABLE" and getField_stack_lightStatus() using the API.

There are a handful of other comforts that are useful for groups with limited resources. Check out the Panel/Alliance E-stops that create virtual E-stop and A-stops if you dont have phyisical ones.

image481Ã—238 8.2 KB

I have a long road ahead of me to get eveything well documented for others to copy. There are a few that have been successful. Here are a few photos from my weekend in the garage as I get ready for the fall Minnesota Offseason events that I will be at.
